name: M&M Mezcal Montenegro
instructions:
1. Start by stirring all your ingredients together with ice in a mixing glass, ensuring they're well combined
2. Aim to stir for about 10-15 seconds; this integrates everything smoothly without diluting the drink too much
3. Carefully pour this mixture through a strainer into a glass filled with ice, ideally a single large ice block, to keep your drink cold longer with less dilution
description:
The M & M is a sophisticated cocktail that skillfully combines the deep, herbal flavors of Amaro with the smoky complexity of Mezcal. Served in a cocktail glass, this concoction is a testament to the art of blending contrasting spirits to create a harmony of flavors.

Ideal for those who appreciate a drink with depth and character, the M & M offers a unique tasting experience that seamlessly melds the bitter nuances of Amaro with the rich, smoky notes of Mezcal. This cocktail is perfectly suited for sipping slowly on a relaxed evening, allowing the palate to explore the intricate dance between its bold ingredients.

ingredients.name: Amaro Montenegro
ingredients.description: Although not as popular as Averna, Montenegro packs an incredible bouquet of flavors ranging from carmel and chocolate to chartreuse-like herbals, all at a very workable price. As an added bonus, Montenegro is delicious on the rocks and sports an eye-catching bottle.

ingredients.name: Mezcal
ingredients.description:
Mezcal is a distilled alcoholic beverage that originates from Mexico, known for its distinctive smoky flavor. It is made from the agave plant, primarily the species Agave espadin, although other agave varieties can be used. The production of mezcal involves roasting the agave hearts (pi√±as) in underground pits, which imparts a smoky character to the final product. After roasting, the agave is crushed, fermented, and then distilled, resulting in a spirit with a wide range of flavors, including earthy, fruity, and herbal notes.

The traditional production methods involve cooking the agave in earthen pits lined with lava rocks and filled with wood and charcoal. This underground roasting process gives mezcal its distinctive smoky taste.

Mezcal is produced in specific regions of Mexico, with Oaxaca being a particularly renowned area for its high-quality mezcals. The production of mezcal is regulated, and the spirit has a Denomination of Origin (DO) to ensure authenticity and quality.

Unlike some other agave spirits, such as tequila, which is made from Blue Agave, mezcal can be produced from a variety of agave types, contributing to the spirit's diversity.

Mezcal is deeply rooted in Mexican culture and has gained international recognition for its artisanal production methods and diverse flavor profile.
